review.title: Possibilistic Pertinence Feedback and Semantic Networks for Goal's Extraction
review.abstract: Pertinence Feedback is a technique that enables a user to interactively express his information requirement by modifying his original query formulation with further information. This information is provided by explicitly confirming the pertinent of some indicating objects and/or goals extracted by the system. Obviously the user cannot mark objects and/or goals as pertinent until some are extracted, so the first search has to be initiated by a query and the initial query specification has to be good enough to pick out some pertinent objects and/or goals from the Semantic Network. In this paper we present a short survey of fuzzy and Semantic approaches to Knowledge Extraction. The goal of such approaches is to define flexible Knowledge Extraction Systems able to deal with the inherent vagueness and uncertainty of the Extraction process. It has long been recognised that interactivity improves the effectiveness of Knowledge Extraction systems. Novice user's queries are the most natural and interactive medium of communication and recent progress in recognition is making it possible to build systems that interact with the user. However, given the typical novice user's queries submitted to Knowledge Extraction Systems, it is easy to imagine that the effects of goal recognition errors in novice user's queries must be severely destructive on the system's effectiveness. The experimental work reported in this paper shows that the use of possibility theory in classical Knowledge Extraction techniques for novice user's query processing is more robust than the use of the probability theory. Moreover, both possibilistic and probabilistic pertinence feedback can be effectively employed to improve the effectiveness of novice user's query processing.

sections.text: Pertinence feedback is a technique that allows a user to express their request for information interactively by modifying their original search query formulation with additional information. This information is provided by explicitly confirming the relevance of some of the objects and / or targets extracted from the system. Obviously, the user cannot mark objects and / or targets as relevant until some are extracted, so the first search must be initiated by a query and the first query specification must be good enough to pick out some relevant objects and / or targets from the semantic network. In this paper, we present a brief overview of blurred and semantic approaches to knowledge extraction, the goal of which is to define flexible knowledge extraction systems capable of dealing with the inherent fuzziness and uncertainty of the extraction process. It has long been recognized that interactivity improves the effectiveness of knowledge extraction systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The effectiveness of a KES is therefore crucial to the system's ability to deal with the vagueness and uncertainty of the extraction process. Commercially available KES ignore these aspects; they simplify both the presentation of the content of a KES and the interaction between users. The goal of a KES is to extract knowledge relevant to a user's request, expressed in natural language. Pertinence of the feedback of a KES is measured by parameters that reflect the system's ability to achieve such a goal. The essence of the goal is not deterministic, since uncertainty and ambiguity exist in the various parts of the extraction process. The expression of knowledge in a request is uncertain and often vague, the representation of an object in an object.

sections.heading: 2. Fuzzy Goals and Fuzzy Objects
sections.text: Much research has been done in the theory of possibility on the term "knowledge extraction." To expand the definition of knowledge (goal) extraction from fuzzy sets to fuzzy goals, we must first analyze how to describe fuzzy objects and goals in terms of fuzzy sets [3, 4]. How does a user formulate his or her goals? How do we describe a goal, for example, when looking for a house? A natural goal is to have a car that is not too old, not too expensive, a red color, etc., to describe a goal in general: • we list attributes (in the example above, age, cost, and color), and • we list the desired (fuzzy) value A1,..., One of these attributes (in the example above, these attributes are correspondingly "too fuzzy, object not too expensive, and color), and • we list the desired (fuzzy) value A1,...

sections.heading: 3. Knowledge Extraction System
sections.text: In this paper we will apply to KE three theories that have been used in artificial intelligence for quite some time: possibility, probability and SN theories. The use of these techniques in KE was recently used as knowledge extraction in analogy to the fields of computing and information retrieval [5, 6]. Fuzzy set theory [7] is a formal framework well suited to improve model vagance: in information retrieval it has been successfully employed on several levels [8, 9], in particular for the definition of a superstructure of the Boolean model [10], with the attractive consequence that Boolean KESs can be improved without completely redesigning them.

sections.heading: 6. Experimental Analysis
sections.text: We decided to compare the two techniques (PPF and PRF) to see if one was better from an experimental point of view than the other, motivated by the results of an earlier study comparing the results of the two previously described techniques [3]. In this study, we discovered that PPF was performed as well as PRF, taking into account the best possible parameter settings, but different sets of objects were extracted. The experiments described in this paper are more precise, use larger data sets, and aim to test the possibility of combining the two techniques. We decided to perform our analysis according to the classic experimental methodology of KE, using KE effectiveness measurements and KE test collections. The most important measures used in KE are persistent extraction and precision. Object-persient extraction (Op) is the subset of all objects in the collections that are relevant to a query and are actually extracted.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experimental and Evaluation Settings
sections.text: The object collections selected for investigation are the word processor program and the application test collections of the phone. The main features of these two test collections are summarized in Table 1. These are classic KE test collections used by our researchers on site and described in [3, 4]. At the current stage of our research it was not about efficiency issues, and we decided that size was not that important. There are still many open questions in applying SN to KE, and the problem of scaling the results is one of the most important. We are aware of the fact that the collections used in our experiments can be considered small from the point of view of KE.

sections.heading: 6.2 Comparing Probabilistic Relevance and Possibilistic Pertinence Feedback
sections.text: Since our first comparative look at PRF and PRF, we noticed that the set of targets added to the original query was very different. In other words, by taking the same initial query and returning the same objects to the PPF and PRF, we obtained different objectives (and different weights for the same targets) added to the query. In a test of 25 queries randomly selected from the series of queries from our word processor, we found that the difference between the two groups of m (m = 10) targets to be added to the query was an average of 28%, i.e., at least 3 targets that were different. The difference in weights between the same targets present in both groups was an average of 87%. Analogous differences were found from the other test collections. We compared the performance of PRF and PPF with the training groups of different sizes. Figures 1 and 2 illustrate how the performance of PF and PRF are similar to the number of relevant objects obtained when the PRF is applicable to the number of PRF.

sections.heading: 7. Limitations
sections.text: In this paper, we present a study on the effectiveness of possible and likely relevant feedback on the processing of queries by beginners. We have reported in the previous sections on some of the results of an analysis of the impact of the use of possibility and probability theories in user queries on the effectiveness of a KE system. We believe that the work presented here is complete because it uses a larger number of query sets, a larger collection of objects, and a more classical KE system that was not matched to the test collection used. Nevertheless, there are at least two important limitations of this study: 1. The collection of queries used in the experiment was not really representative of typical queries by beginners. However, it has long been known that queries by beginners mainly depend on the application domain and the KE environment.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and futur works
sections.text: In this paper, the summarized results of this study show that a PPF-based persistence feedback device is more effective than PRF at a low level of training. A low level of training (i.e. a small number of objects indicated by the user as relevant) is typical of real-world KE applications. However, since PPF and PRF identify different targets at each level of training that need to be added to those included in the original query, a combination of PPF and PRF may prove effective. Results in this direction appear to indicate that the combination is indeed effective. However, further testing with larger collections of objects and with different algorithms for PPF and PRF is needed to confirm these results and fully exploit their usefulness.
